stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Conficker Worm Botnet Attack Observed in the Financial Services Sector
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
On June 15, 2018, a trusted third party observed a coordinated Conficker worm botnet attack originating from multiple source IP addresses identified as part of a botnet:
185.62.190.191 27.253.114.234 80.177.110.90 87.192.220.188 103.40.202.46 151.42.150.108 177.21.201.1 62.170.84.46 73.183.147.251 79.195.220.44 80.177.110.90 85.75.228.154 87.192.220.188 92.104.164.68 103.40.202.46 151.42.150.108 188.80.70.196 218.221.239.232
The IP address "185.62.190.191" was also identified as a destination IP of outbound command and control (C2) traffic generating connection attempts to the malicious URL "http://185.62.190.191/r%20-O%20-%3E%20/tmp/r;sh%20/tmp/r%27$". This URL string is related to a D-Link router vulnerability and exploit.
According to open source analysis, to spread, this worm exploits the Server Service Vulnerability (CVE-2008-4250), as written in the Microsoft Security Bulletin MS08-067. CVE-2008-4250 indicates that the Server service in Microsoft Windows 2000 SP4, XP SP2 and SP3, Server 2003 SP1 and SP2, Vista Gold and SP1, Server 2008, and 7 Pre-Beta allows remote attackers to execute arbitrary code via a crafted RPC request that triggers the overflow during path canonicalization, as exploited in the wild in October 2008, aka "Server Service Vulnerability."
According to open source analysis Win32/Conficker has multiple propagation methods. These include the following:
- Exploitation of the vulnerability that is patched by security update 958644 (MS08-067) - The use of network shares - The use of AutoPlay functionality
This activity was observed in the Financial Services sector.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Title: Malicious IPv4 Indicator
stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
According to the trusted third party, source IP address "185.62.190.191" was identified as a malicious participant in coordinated Conficker worm botnet attack. The same IP has been also identified by the third party as the destination IP of outbound C2 traffic generating connection attempts to the malicious URL "http://185.62.190.191/r%20-O%20-%3E%20/tmp/r;sh%20/tmp/r%27$".
The trusted third party has indicated that all listed above source IP addresses were associated with generating the following resource URL "http://127.0.0.1/login.cgi?cli=aa%20aa%27;wget%20".
According to open source analysis, "127.0.0.1" is the loopback IP address also referred to as the "localhost". The address is used to establish an IP connection to the same machine or computer being used by the end-user. Application software typically uses this loopback feature for local testing purposes. Messages sent to loopback IP addresses like 127.0.0.1 do not reach outside to the local area network (LAN) but instead are delivered directly to the TCP/IP and receive queues as if they had arrived from an outside source.
According to open source analysis, the observed URL format "http://127.0.0.1/login.cgi?cli=aa%20aa%27;wget%20" has been linked to "D-Link DSL-2750B - OS Command Injection (Metasploit)". This Metasploit module exploits a remote command injection vulnerability in D-Link DSL-2750B devices. Vulnerability can be exploited through "cli" parameter that is directly used to invoke "ayecli" binary. Vulnerable firmwares are from 1.01 up to 1.03.
At the time of analysis, the below WHOIS information was associated with IP "185.62.190.191":
IP Location Russian Federation Russian Federation Severodvinsk Nforce Entertainment B.v. Reverse IP indicates that 7 websites use this IP address. ASN Russian Federation AS49349 DOTSI, PT (registered May 25, 2009) Resolve Host nigeria.is.cool Whois Server whois.ripe.net IP Address 185.62.190.191 inetnum: 185.62.190.0 - 185.62.190.255 netname: BlazingFast descr: BlazingFast LLC org: ORG-BL212-RIPE country: NL admin-c: BFAR tech-c: BFTR status: ASSIGNED PA created: 2015-11-05T12:01:26Z last-modified: 2015-11-05T12:01:26Z source: RIPE organisation: ORG-BL212-RIPE org-name: BlazingFast LLC org-type: OTHER address: 87/30, Zhylianska Street, Office 402 address: Kyiv 01032, Kyiv Oblast address: Ukraine e-mail: admin@blazingfast.io abuse-c: BN2386-RIPE created: 2015-03-19T09:42:27Z last-modified: 2015-03-19T09:42:27Z source: RIPE person: BlazingFast LLC - Administrative role account address: 87/30, Zhylianska Street, Office 402 address: Kyiv 01032, Kyiv Oblast address: Ukraine phone: +380000000000 e-mail: administration@blazingfast.io

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Phishing Email with Price List Theme Leads to FormBook and Eldorado Malware
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
On June 20, 2018, a trusted third party observed a phishing email sent from "inter@bmmetal.co.kr" with the subject line "Re: Fwd: 20th June 2018/Price list". The phishing email contained the file "Price_list#200618.xlsx" [MD5: 32cafed5656665e75c119243c1fd6082], which made a GET request to the URL "http://23.249.161.109/wrd/zomamez.exe", which subsequently dropped the file [MD5: 28b1486b971c309e82db3409963a188e]. The dropped file was detected as FormBook and Eldorado malware. The trusted third party then observed traffic to the following URLs:
http://www.aibbybrown-music.com http://www.chizhar.biz http://www.dzairshopping.com http://www.inspectah.tech http://www.libaowuzi.com http://www.lucanossan.com http://www.pyemnjqti.download http://www.riaoao3.com
Eldorado is a potentially unwanted program (PUP) typically bundled with other software using custom installers and dropped on the infected computer during the installation process. The malware is capable of modifying system files, adding new folders, creating Windows tasks, and showing advertisements on the victim's computer and browser.
FormBook is a data stealer and form grabber that has been advertised in various hacking forums since early 2016. The malware injects itself into various processes and installs function hooks to log keystrokes, steal clipboard contents, and extract data from HTTP sessions. The malware can also execute commands from a command and control (C2) server. The commands include instructing the malware to download and execute files, start processes, shutdown and reboot the system, and steal cookies and local passwords.
This activity was observed in the Financial Services sector.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Title: Malicious File Indicator
stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
According to the trusted third party, a threat actor using the email address "inter@bmmetal.co.kr" sent a phishing email with the subject line "Re: Fwd: 20th June 2018/Price list" contained the file "Price_list#200618.xlsx" [MD5: 32cafed5656665e75c119243c1fd6082].
Open-source analysis indicates that the file "Price_list#200618.xlsx" [MD5: 32cafed5656665e75c119243c1fd6082] is categorized as malicious and as a Trojan or Microsoft Office exploit by multiple antivirus engines. According to the trusted third party, this file exploits a MS Equation Editor vulnerability.
Microsoft Equation Editor, which is a Microsoft Office component, contains a stack buffer overflow vulnerability (CVE-2017-11882) that enables remote code execution on a vulnerable system and can allow an attacker to write a mathematical equation into a document.

This file made a GET request to the URL "http://23.249.161.109/wrd/zomamez.exe", which subsequently dropped the file [MD5: 28b1486b971c309e82db3409963a188e].

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Phishing Email with Quotation Request Theme Leads to Adwind Malware
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
On June 27, 2018, a trusted third party reported a phishing email from "Boris Samantha" <r.alexieva@elmarkgroup.eu> with the subject line "Quotation Request". The email included the URL "https://app.box.com/shared/static/xafu25yted2slsivdg0fh7os6sh2fhr2.zip", which led to the zipped file "xafu25yted2slsivdg0fh7os6sh2fhr2.zip" that contained the malicious file "Quatation list_pdf.jar" [MD5: f10d0cf4494129905ad47c85307be015]. Once installed, the malware called out to the command and control (C2) IP address "192.241.103.4" using port 2122.
According to open-source research, antivirus engines may identify "Quatation list_pdf.jar" [MD5: f10d0cf4494129905ad47c85307be015] as Adwind malware.
Adwind (aka Unrecom, JSocket, JBifrost, Frutas, and AlienSpy) is a Trojan developed in Java that can run on multiple operating systems such as Windows, Mac OS, and Linux. The Trojan may be delivered as an attachment in malicious emails and is capable of performing various tasks including: taking screenshots, accessing the webcam, accessing the file system to read, write, or delete files, downloading and executing files, logging keystrokes, recording audio, and tampering with input devices.
This activity was observed in the Financial Services sector.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Targeted Phishing Emails Observed in the Energy Sector
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
On June 26, 2018, a trusted third party reported multiple phishing emails from the following senders with the following subject lines:
Sender: "ng.nguyen@gmail.com", Subject: "REQUEST FOR QUOTATION", Received on: 04/12/2018 Sender: "shirley.limi@gardnerdenver.com", Subject: "Purchase Order", Received on: 04/15/2018 Sender: "huonggang@mppl.com.vn", Subject: "REQUEST FOR QUOTATION", Received on: 04/18/2018 Sender: "tylerd@vdctn.com", Subject: "Revised invoice", Received on: 06/14/2018
The first three phishing emails were sent from the IP address "23.92.216.215". One of these phishing emails contained an attachment which was detected as "trojan.agent.cbgz", however, no additional information was provided.
The last email was a targeted phishing email sent from "tylerd@vdctn.com" with the subject "Revised invoice". The email included a link to the malicious URL "https://securefile.qpr8.download/file.php?login=[REDACTED EMAIL]&name=". The URL specifically linked the recipient’s email address within it, probably for tracking purposes. The email originated from "23.92.216.197".
All four phishing emails originated from IP range "23.92.216.192/26", which is registered to "Centrilogic, Inc." in Rochester, MA.
Trojan.Agent is generic name for Trojans detected via heuristic detection methods.
This activity was observed in the Energy sector.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Title: Malicious E-mail Indicator
stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
According to the trusted third party, a targeted phishing email with the subject "Revised invoice" was sent from the compromised account "tylerd@vdctn.com". The email included a link to the malicious URL "https://securefile.qpr8.download/file.php?login=[REDACTED EMAIL]&name=". The URL specifically linked the recipient’s email address within it, probably for tracking purposes.
According to open-source research, this email address has possibly been compromised and leveraged to deliver phishing emails.
At the time of analysis, the below WHOIS information was associated with the email domain "vdctn.com".

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Smishing Scam Leads to Credential Harvesting Site
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
On June 29, 2018, a trusted third party reported a "government refund" themed SMiShing message from an actor masquerading as "DVLA (Driver and Vehicle Licensing Agency)". The message contained the malicious URL "http://govdvlrefund.com/?ID=ABCDEF" [IP address: 72.9.105.250]. Once the victim submits information on the phishing site, an error message is displayed and asks the user to click on one of the following banks sites: Barclays, Halifax, HSBC, Llyods Bank, Natwest, Royal Bank of Scotland, Santander, TSB, Metro Bank, Clydesdale Bank, The co-operative bank, and Tesco Bank.
This activity was observed in the Financial Services sector.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Offer for Purchase Themed Phishing Email Observed in the Financial Sector
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
On June 29, 2018, a trusted third party reported phishing emails from "paulo@novahometeam.com" with the attachment "Offer for Purchase.PDF", which had the embedded URL "http://lopiefuhf.ml/wp-admin/docpage/gieeedoc/melstod.php". No further information was provided.
According to open-source reporting, the URL "http://lopiefuhf.ml/wp-admin/docpage/gieeedoc/melstod.php" is malicious.
This activity was observed in the Financial Services sector.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Phishing Email Targeted Financial Services Sector
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
On July 2, 2018, a trusted third party reported a phishing email with the subject "copy". The email included the malicious attachment "ID_copy(25.06).iqy.7z" [MD5: f1720132086660a4b95fc3ea28f0c3e2], which contained the malicious file "ID_copy(25.06).iqy" [MD5: 1db49b694022ecae61b55fee02e6da36]. Once the file [MD5: 1db49b694022ecae61b55fee02e6da36] was executed, HTTP GET requests were made for the following URLs:
"http://147.135.170.169/pre.dat" "http://147.135.170.169/ld.dat" "http://147.135.170.169/bomb.dat" "http://147.135.170.169/kernel.dat".
The GET requests resulted in the download of the following files:
"pre.dat" [MD5: 375cdf2fab4c92dcea617660909bcdfd] "ld.dat" [MD5: 556e762171d19dc653084fbe3370852c] "bomb.dat" [MD5: 1666fb514591f1b49bbf9b4a06ef005e] "kernel.dat" (encrypted payload) [MD5: 365a4d79e6354da6eaaff58457003a53]
The file hash of the decrypted payload was [MD5: e88c7dedbabd629fa77f26fbef2b340c]. Once executed, "wsus.exe" [MD5: e88c7dedbabd629fa77f26fbef2b340c] called out to IP address "103.208.86.39".
This activity was observed in the Financial Services sector.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Title: Malicious File Indicator
stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
According to the trusted third party, this malicious attachment was included in a phishing email targeting Financial Services sector employees. The attachment contained the malicious file "ID_copy(25.06).iqy" [MD5: 1db49b694022ecae61b55fee02e6da36].
According to open-source research, antivirus engines may identify the file [MD5: f1720132086660a4b95fc3ea28f0c3e2] as a Trojan downloader.
A Trojan downloader is a type of malware that installs itself on the system and waits until an Internet connection becomes available to connect to a remote server or website in order to download additional programs (usually malware) onto the infected computer. The malicious files are typically labeled using legitimate sounding program or document names, such as "invoice" or "accounts.exe", as a simple form of social engineering. On opening the file attachment, the Trojan downloader is installed.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Title: Malicious File Indicator
stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
According to the trusted third party, this file was contained in the file [MD5: f1720132086660a4b95fc3ea28f0c3e2]. Once the file was downloaded and executed, HTTP GET requests were made to "http://147.135.170.169/pre.dat", "http://147.135.170.169/ld.dat", "http://147.135.170.169/bomb.dat", and "http://147.135.170.169/kernel.dat".
According to open-source research, antivirus engines may identify the file [MD5: 1db49b694022ecae61b55fee02e6da36] as a Trojan downloader.
A Trojan downloader is a type of malware that installs itself on the system and waits until an Internet connection becomes available to connect to a remote server or website in order to download additional programs (usually malware) onto the infected computer. The malicious files are typically labeled using legitimate sounding program or document names, such as "invoice" or "accounts.exe", as a simple form of social engineering. On opening the file attachment, the Trojan downloader is installed.

stix:Indicator.indicator:Title: Malicious URL Indicator
stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
According to the trusted third party, once the malicious file "ID_copy(25.06).iqy" [MD5: 1db49b694022ecae61b55fee02e6da36] was downloaded and executed it initiated an HTTP request to this URL, which resulted in the download of the malicious file "pre.dat" [MD5: 375cdf2fab4c92dcea617660909bcdfd].
According to open-source research, this URL was previously used as a malware delivery site. At the time of analysis, the below WHOIS information was associated with the IP address "147.135.170.169".

stix:Indicator.indicator:Title: Malicious File Indicator
stix:Indicator.indicator:Description:
According to the trusted third party, "bomb.dat" [MD5: 1666fb514591f1b49bbf9b4a06ef005e] was downloaded from the malicious URL "http://147.135.170.169/bomb.dat".
According to open-source research, antivirus engines may identify this file as Artemis.
Artemis is a malware that affects the operation of web browsers. The most common signs of infection by the Artemis virus are browser homepage changes, search engine queries being redirected to advertisement pages, and new browser windows with pop-up ads.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Extortion Email Sent to Financial Services Partner
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
On July 3, 2018, a trusted third party observed an email sent from "osmw@droomspeelbus.nl" (Originating IP address "37.128.144.143") with the subject line "I don't know when ever you gonna love it or not, however you really should read it". This activity was determined to be an extortion email demanding payment to a bitcoin wallet (Bitcoin address: 1Jg7fdt8SkAMJe9NWRWEBjz9SYur1woGtM) in the amount of $360 US Dollars. At the time of this incident, the Bitcoin wallet was active with no observed transactions.
This activity was observed in the Financial Services sector.

stix:STIX_Header.stix:Title: Identification of Tax Themed Malware Landing Pages
stix:STIX_Header.stix:Description:
On June 26, 2018, a trusted third party reported the URLs "http://www.arfilm.ru/IRS-Transcripts-7685/", "http://rialesva.cl/IRS-Accounts-Transcipts-June-2018-6414/", and "http:///irs-docs.com" as IRS and tax-themed malware landing pages.
Antivirus programs detected the malware on these pages as Valyria or other Visual Basic downloader.
Valyria is a Windows-based Trojan that creates a backdoor on the compromised machine. The malware is capable of installing keyloggers, monitoring activity, stealing account information, and exfiltrating files.
This activity was observed in the Financial Services sector.
